section.title: Cinnamon Rolls

listitem.para: 2 eggs (my recipe says "slightly beaten" but I never beat them before adding them)

section.para: Prepare cold mixture and then hot mixture. Combine hot and cold mixtures in the large bowl, and stir. Water should now be warm, so add the yeast mixture to it.

Mix in approx. 7 cups of flour. These days I use self raising flour, but it works with regular flour too. As you're adding in the last cup or two of flour, you'll likely need to mix by hand. You want the dough to feel "doughy", which is to saying springy and not sticky. Do not over work it.
Set bowl aside in warm place (we used to put on top of water heater), covered by clean dish towel to rise. That'll take an hour or two. If you have time, you can punch down and let rise again.
Now you're ready to play! Put some flour down on work surface, take out half the dough and start kneading, adding flour as needed. Again, don't add too much or the bread will be heavy and dense.

At this point, you can form into loaves and put into buttered loaf tins to bake as bread. Or you can roll in small balls (inch and a bit in diameter), and put three balls into each buttered muffin well to make dinner rolls. Either way, let it rise again in warm place. When ready, put in oven and bake for 25 minutes in 350 degree oven, or until golden brown.
If you want to make the cinnamon rolls, see extra steps below to make the cinnamon sugar mix and prepare the pans for baking. Then, work your dough as described in the following paragraphs.

Knead dough, as above. After you've finished kneading the dough, roll it out nice and thin (maybe quarter of an inch thick), into a basically rectangular shape. Spread with butter (I find melting butter and brushing it on works well. At least used softened butter!). Now sprinkle on cinnamon sugar mixture (which you've made in advance), nice and thick (don't skimp on the filling). Add chopped nuts if you like (pecans..yum!). Roll the dough lengthwise into a long thin log (as opposed to a short thick one). Cut into sections a couple of inches wide.
You (having read these instructions before starting) took the time to prepare the cinnamon roll pans prior to rolling out the dough as shown in the extra steps. If not, do it now!

Place the cut rolls into the pan, cut side down, three or four to a row. Don't cram them in too tight, since you want to let them rise again before baking. As you fill each pan, cover and put in warm place to rise. If you end up with just a few left, we've also baked in prepared pie pans.

When they've risen (maybe 30 or 45 minutes), bake in 350 degree oven about 25 minutes or until golden brown. Place foil on a cooking rack, longer than the baking dish and tip the rolls out to cool. You'll want to put the dish in water quickly, cause the sticky goop hardens as it cools. Of course I like to scrape it up with a spoon and later suck it like a lollipop, but that's me! Or try to get the extra goop back on to the rolls (easier said than done).

Delicious served warm (or reheated) with a bit of butter on top. To store for short term, put saran wrap on top, after they've cooled, and fold the tin foil up over edges. Generally I refrigerate, but I think they're fine on the counter too. If you want to freeze a half batch for later, wrap whole foiled and saran wrapped package in yet more foil.

para.emphasis: Dogs love these. One dog of mine took half a pan of cooled rolls right off the counter. She didn't even mind the spanking. She said it was totally worth it!
This is where it gets fun, because I completely do this to taste. Haven't followed a recipe in eons. Word to the wise, use more cinnamon than you think you need. Lots more.

section.para: Basically, 2 parts white sugar to 1 part brown sugar. You should probably end up with at least a couple of cups when you're done. If you don't use it all, save itâ€¦works great for cinnamon toast, too. Add lots of cinnamon. Also a bit of nutmeg. I've even tossed in a splash of ginger. Mix together. If you want, let me know, and I'll go look up the actual proportions.

Take a couple of cake pans or glass casserole dishes and butter the bottoms and sides. Drizzle the bottom with Karo syrup. Don't cover it completely, since it will melt and spread as it heats up. Sprinkle more cinnamon sugar mix and chopped nuts over the whole bottom of the pan.
